title: Introduction to Ubuntu
note: Explains that Ubuntu is a popular, user-friendly Linux distribution based on Debian. Covers the difference between the stable Long-Term Support (LTS) releases and the regular six-month releases.

title: Installing Ubuntu Desktop and Navigating GNOME
note: Covers creating a bootable USB and installing Ubuntu Desktop. Provides a guided tour of the GNOME desktop environment, including the Activities overview, the Dock, and the Software Center.

title: Introduction to the Command Line (Terminal)
note: Introduces the command line as the most powerful way to interact with Linux. Covers essential navigation and file management commands: `pwd`, `ls`, `cd`, `mkdir`, `cp`, `mv`, and `rm`.

title: Getting Help and Running Commands as an Administrator
note: Explains how to use `man` and `--help` to get documentation. Introduces `sudo` for running commands with administrative privileges.

title: Software Management with `apt`
note: Introduces `apt` as the command-line tool for managing software. Covers the main commands: `sudo apt update`, `upgrade`, `install <package>`, and `remove <package>`.

title: Managing Software Sources and PPAs
note: Explains how `apt` uses repositories defined in `/etc/apt/sources.list`. Demonstrates how to add third-party software sources using Personal Package Archives (PPAs).

title: Managing Users and Groups
note: Covers user and group administration. Demonstrates `adduser`, `usermod`, `deluser` for user management, and `addgroup` for creating groups.

title: Understanding File Permissions
note: Explains the Linux file permission model: read (r), write (w), and execute (x) for the user, group, and others. Covers using `chmod` to change permissions and `chown` to change ownership.

title: Managing Processes
note: Covers how to view and manage running processes. Introduces `ps` to see a snapshot of processes, `top` and `htop` for real-time monitoring, and `kill`/`pkill` to terminate processes.

title: Viewing Logs with `journalctl`
note: Explains how to use `journalctl`, the tool for querying the `systemd` journal. Demonstrates how to view all logs, filter by service or time, and follow logs in real time.

title: Automating Tasks with Cron
note: Introduces the `cron` daemon for scheduling recurring tasks. Explains the `crontab` file format and demonstrates how to edit it with `crontab -e` to schedule scripts to run automatically.

title: Introduction to Ubuntu Server
note: Discusses Ubuntu Server, highlighting the text-based installer and lack of a default GUI. Introduces remote administration as the primary way to manage a server.

title: Connecting Remotely and Securely with SSH
note: Introduces SSH for remote command-line access. Explains how to connect with `ssh user@hostname` and covers the critical security practice of disabling password authentication in favor of SSH keys.

title: Managing Services with `systemd`
note: Covers managing background services (daemons) with `systemd`. Introduces `systemctl` for starting, stopping, enabling, disabling, and checking the status of services.

title: Configuring the Firewall with UFW
note: Introduces `ufw` (Uncomplicated Firewall). Demonstrates how to enable the firewall, check its status, and create rules to allow or deny traffic for specific services like SSH and HTTP.

title: Server Networking with Netplan
note: Explains that modern Ubuntu servers use Netplan for network configuration via YAML files in `/etc/netplan`. Covers basic configuration for a static IP address.

title: Disk and Filesystem Management
note: Covers fundamental disk management. Introduces `lsblk`, `df`, and `du` for viewing disks and usage. Explains how to partition a disk with `fdisk`, create a filesystem with `mkfs`, and mount it persistently in `/etc/fstab`.

title: Introduction to LVM (Logical Volume Management)
note: Introduces LVM as a flexible way to manage storage. Explains the concepts of Physical Volumes (PVs), Volume Groups (VGs), and Logical Volumes (LVs), which can be resized easily.

title: Universal Packages with Snap
note: Introduces Snaps as containerized software packages that bundle their dependencies. Demonstrates the `snap install`, `remove`, and `list` commands.

title: Cloud Server Initialization with `cloud-init`
note: Introduces `cloud-init`, the industry standard for early initialization of cloud instances. Explains how it uses user-data (e.g., cloud-config files) to configure networking, users, and install packages on first boot.
